action.action-desc: Mr. Lipinski (for himself, Mr. Hultgren, Mr. Collins of New York, Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas, Ms. Esty, Ms. Wilson of Florida, Ms. Kelly of Illinois, and Mr. Kennedy) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology

form.official-title: To provide for the establishment of a body to identify and coordinate international science and technology cooperation that can strengthen the domestic science and technology enterprise and support United States foreign policy goals.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the International Science and Technology Cooperation Act of 2014.

section.header: Coordination of international science and technology partnerships

subsection.text: The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy shall establish a body under the National Science and Technology Council with the responsibility to identify and coordinate international science and technology cooperation that can strengthen the United States science and technology enterprise, improve economic and national security, and support United States foreign policy goals.
The body established under subsection (a) shall be co-chaired by senior level officials from the Office of Science and Technology Policy and the Department of State.
The body established under subsection (a) shall—

paragraph.text: coordinate interagency international science and technology cooperative research and training activities and partnerships supported or managed by Federal agencies and work with other National Science and Technology Council committees to help plan and coordinate the international component of national science and technology priorities;

establish Federal priorities and policies for aligning, as appropriate, international science and technology cooperative research and training activities and partnerships supported or managed by Federal agencies with the foreign policy goals of the United States;

in carrying out paragraph (3), solicit input and recommendations from non-Federal science and technology stakeholders, including universities, scientific and professional societies, industry, and relevant organizations and institutions; and

identify broad issues that influence the ability of United States scientists and engineers to collaborate with foreign counterparts, including barriers to collaboration and access to scientific information.

subsection.text: The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy shall transmit a report, to be updated annually, to the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives, and to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate. The report shall also be made available to the public on the reporting agency’s website. The report shall contain a description of—

paragraph.text: the priorities and policies established under subsection (c)(2);
the ongoing and new partnerships established since the last update to the report;
the means by which stakeholder input was received, as well as summary views of stakeholder input; and
the issues influencing the ability of United States scientists and engineers to collaborate with foreign counterparts.
